channel.title: NPR Topics: News
channel.description: NPR news, audio, and podcasts. Coverage of breaking stories, national and world news, politics, business, science, technology, and extended coverage of major national and world events.
channel.copyright: Copyright 2024 NPR - For Personal Use Only

item.title: Israel says the latest remains returned from Gaza are not bodies of hostages
item.description: The remains of three people handed over by Hamas to the Red Cross this week do not belong to any of the hostages, Israel said, the latest setback that could undermine a U.S.-brokered ceasefire.
item.content:encoded:
The remains of three people handed over by Hamas to the Red Cross this week do not belong to any of the hostages, Israel said, the latest setback that could undermine a U.S.-brokered ceasefire.

(Image credit: Abdel Kareem Hana)
item.dc:creator: The Associated Press

item.title: Opinion: Forget the East Wing, let's take state dinners to the fair
item.description: A ballroom at the White House could seat nearly a 1,000 guests for state dinners, but what to do while it's being built? NPR's Scott Simon suggests holding state dinners at the Iowa State Fairgrounds.
item.content:encoded:
A ballroom at the White House could seat nearly a 1,000 guests for state dinners, but what to do while it's being built? NPR's Scott Simon suggests holding state dinners at the Iowa State Fairgrounds.

(Image credit: Manuel Balce Ceneta/AP)
item.dc:creator: Scott Simon

item.title: Too many rats? Birth control is one city's answer
item.description: Rats aren't just a nuisance. They can carry diseases and are a leading causes of property damage. One community in Massachusetts is trying a novel approach to rat reduction: Birth control.
item.content:encoded:
Rats aren't just a nuisance. They can carry diseases and are a leading causes of property damage. One community in Massachusetts is trying a novel approach to rat reduction: Birth control.

(Image credit: Wirestock)
item.dc:creator: Ari Daniel

item.title: How a great-grandmother helped researchers unravel a dinosaur mummy mystery
item.description: A paleontologist was trying to locate the site of a famous 1908 discovery when a rancher in Wyoming shared an important clue.
item.content:encoded:
A paleontologist was trying to locate the site of a famous 1908 discovery when a rancher in Wyoming shared an important clue.

(Image credit: Tyler Keillor)
item.dc:creator: Bill Chappell

item.title: In redistricting vote, some Californians fear losing out, others want to face Trump
item.description: California's vote Tuesday on whether to redistrict congressional seats could be important in determining who controls Congress after the 2026 midterm elections.
item.content:encoded:
California's vote Tuesday on whether to redistrict congressional seats could be important in determining who controls Congress after the 2026 midterm elections.

(Image credit: Laura Fitzgerald)
item.dc:creator: Laura Fitzgerald

item.title: As SNAP benefits run dry, 'grocery buddies' are footing their neighbors' food bills
item.description: With federal food aid frozen during the government shutdown, there has been a wave of people rushing to help — sending gift cards or buying groceries for SNAP recipients in their community.
item.content:encoded:
With federal food aid frozen during the government shutdown, there has been a wave of people rushing to help — sending gift cards or buying groceries for SNAP recipients in their community.

(Image credit: Mustafa Hussain for NPR)
item.dc:creator: Juliana Kim

item.title: With the outlook for SNAP benefits uncertain, food banks are warning of a crisis
item.description: More Americans are turning to food banks to help fill the assistance gap, but administrators caution they aren't designed to act as a safety net for a government program.
item.content:encoded:
More Americans are turning to food banks to help fill the assistance gap, but administrators caution they aren't designed to act as a safety net for a government program.

(Image credit: Matthew Hatcher)
item.dc:creator: Barbara Sprunt

item.title: Election Day is Tuesday. Here are 5 questions about what the results might mean
item.description: While too much shouldn't be made out of off-year elections, the Nov. 4 election will be the first major electoral sign of the political mood and what voters think of the president.
item.content:encoded:
While too much shouldn't be made out of off-year elections, the Nov. 4 election will be the first major electoral sign of the political mood and what voters think of the president.

(Image credit: Allen J. Schaben)
item.dc:creator: Domenico Montanaro

item.title: Fewer students are missing school. These state policies may have helped
item.description: A new study says several states are doing the right things to get students to show up to school regularly.
item.content:encoded: A new study says several states are doing the right things to get students to show up to school regularly.
item.dc:creator: Kadin Mills

item.title: Presidents once avoided shutdown travel. This term, Trump has been a frequent flier
item.description: Not counting his golf outings in Virginia, President Trump spent all or part of 14 days outside of Washington, D.C. during the first 31 days of the shutdown.
item.content:encoded:
Not counting his golf outings in Virginia, President Trump spent all or part of 14 days outside of Washington, D.C. during the first 31 days of the shutdown.

(Image credit: Andrew Harnik)
item.dc:creator: Tamara Keith
